title: MSc (2025) - Webscraping and Text Mining
text:
Project date: Fall 2025 (ongoing)
Research question: How do public threats in a diplomatic setting influence later sanctions?
Methodology: Webscraping, text extraction from pdfs, text mining, sentiment analysis, custom language analysis focused on threats
Programs used: R (rvest, chromote, regex), Python, LaTeX
Output: Dataframe with text of 2000 speeches given in the UN on the Russia-Ukraine conflict since 2014.
Relevance: I apply my knowledge of webscraping by finding a way to methodolically find data on UN speeches and automatically download the required speech notes. I use RegEx code to filter relevant speech data out of big text data, allowing for further research applications.

title: MSc (2025) - Machine Learning for Business Analytics
text:
Project date: Spring 2025 (grade: 100/100 points)
Research question: How do machine learning models help health insurance companies predict fraudulent insurance claims and what are the economic benefits of introducing such methods?
Methodology: feature engineering, machine learning models (Random Forests, Gradient Boosting Models), hyperparameter search, threshold finetuning, cost sensitivity analysis.
Programs used: Python, LaTeX
Output: 5 machine learning models, feature importance analysis (SHAP), cost-benefit simulations, firm-focused recommendations, condensed into a 15 pages long management-focused report. My most advanced model won the class’ prediction competition, outscoring the other students by a minimum of 5% in the evaluation metric.
Relevance: This projects showcases my skills in technical analysis and familiarity of working with advanced models to tackle business problems. Furthermore, it shows my method of analysis: evidence-based, creative, high-level, aware of uncertainties and assumptions, focused on a requested end result.

title: BSc thesis (2022) - Webscraping and Sentiment Analysis
text:
Project date: Spring 2022 (grade: 8.5 out of 10)
Research question: How can high-frequency sentiment on twitter be used to predict the U.S. consumer sentiment index?
Methodology: Webscraping, data cleaning, sentiment analysis, standard econometric analysis
Programs used: Python, Stata
Output: A dataframe containing daily, weekly and monthly twitter sentiment on macroeconomic topics such as inflation and unemployment, an econometric model regressing the U.S. consumer sentiment index on these predictors and lagged variants.
Relevance: This thesis shows my interest in working with self-gathered big data, and transforming it into useful aggregates to be used for further analysis. I a world that is becoming more and more data-driven, I am not afraid to think out of the box in order to increase precision and efficiency of estimates (or in this case, obtain a real-time consumer sentiment estimate instead of a lagged survey indicator).

title: MSc thesis (2025-2026) - Introduction of the Unitary Patent
text:
Project date: Fall 2025 - Spring 2026 (ongoing)
Research question: How is the introduction of the Unitary Patent shaping the patent industry, and do renewal and litigation outcomes between Unitary- and non-Unitary patents differ?
Methodology: translating relational databases into a comprehensive dataset, using econometric methods such as matching to construct treatment and control groups and testing outcomes.
Programs used: SQL (PATSTAT platform), R, LaTeX
Output: MSc thesis
Relevance: Conducting econometrically justifyable industry analysis, useful not only for economic research (policy evaluation of the Unitary Patent), but for business purposes as well (Unitary Patent characteristics, gaps in innovation, litigation outcomes likelihood).
